subject: Ethics
title: Obligations to Unborn Generations
description: A micro-lesson that makes Obligations to Unborn Generations usable.

hook.text: You'll never meet your great-great-grandchildren. Do you owe them a livable planet?

buildup.text: Future generations can't consent to the risks we impose. They inherit our pollution, debt, and choices.

discovery.text: Philosopher Derek Parfit argued we have obligations to future people even though their identity depends on our actions.

twist.text: But if our choices determine who exists, can we wrong people whose very existence depends on those choices?

climax.text: The 'non-identity problem' is philosophy's hardest puzzleâ€”yet most people feel the obligation intuitively.

punchline.text: They don't exist yet. We owe them anyway.

quiz.question: What is the 'non-identity problem' in ethics?
options: Future people's identities depend on our choices, so it's unclear if we can wrong them
People in different countries can't have ethical obligations to each other
Animals don't have personal identities and therefore lack rights
